normalised: **Air India: My Love-Hate Relationship (Mostly Hate, T-B-H)**

unnormalised: Okay, folks, let’s talk about Air India. The airline that’s more of an experience than a mode of transportation. I swear, boarding an Air India flight is like stepping back in time… to the 1980s. And not in a cool, retro way. More like a “where’s the legroom and why is my seat sticky” kind of way.
normalised: Okay, folks, let’s talk about Air India. The airline that’s more of an experience than a mode of transportation. I swear, boarding an Air India flight is like stepping back in time… to the nineteen eighties. And not in a cool, retro way. More like a “where’s the legroom and why is my seat sticky” kind of way.

unnormalised: First of all, the delays. Oh, the delays! I once waited 6 hrs at the Delhi airport for a flight to Bangalore. Six hours! I could’ve taken an auto-rickshaw (maybe). They are pretty good at prepone-ing flights when you're least expecting it. The announcement came over the loudspeaker with the urgency of someone announcing the arrival of chai. No explanation, just a casual "Flight AI 404 to Bangalore is delayed indefinitely." Indefinitely! What does that even mean? Am I going to be stuck here until Diwali?

No explanation, just a casual "Flight A-I four hundred and four to Bangalore is delayed indefinitely." Indefinitely! What does that even mean? Am I going to be stuck here until Diwali?

unnormalised: Then there's the food. Airline food, in general, isn't exactly Michelin-star quality, but Air India takes it to a whole new level. My recent trip saw me served what I'm pretty sure was a slightly warmed-over mystery curry with the texture of wallpaper paste. And the dessert? A single, lonely gulab jamun that looked like it had seen better days. I'm starting to think they need a food taster. The portion size of gulab jamun was definitely smaller than 30 grams.

A single, lonely gulab jamun that looked like it had seen better days. I'm starting to think they need a food taster. The portion size of gulab jamun was definitely smaller than thirty grams.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the in-flight entertainment. Let's just say the selection of movies is… eclectic. Think Bollywood films from 2005, grainy Hollywood blockbusters from the early 90s, and a documentary about the migratory habits of the Indian Roller bird. All viewed on a screen the size of a postage stamp. Bring your own entertainment, folks, unless you really want to know about the mating rituals of birds.

Think Bollywood films from two thousand and five, grainy Hollywood blockbusters from the early nineties, and a documentary about the migratory habits of the Indian Roller bird. All viewed on a screen the size of a postage stamp. Bring your own entertainment, folks, unless you really want to know about the mating rituals of birds.

unnormalised: The legroom situation is, shall we say, cozy. Unless you're built like a toothpick, prepare to be intimate with the knees of the person in front of you. I’m 5’10” and feel like I’m being folded into origami every time I fly with them. Pro tip: book an aisle seat, so you can at least stretch your legs into the aisle and hope no one trips over them.

Pro tip: book an aisle seat, so you can at least stretch your legs into the aisle and hope no one trips over them.

unnormalised: But here's the thing: despite all the chaos and questionable culinary choices, I still have a soft spot for Air India. Maybe it's nostalgia. Maybe it's the fact that they are always in time to take you to your destination (eventually). Whatever it is, it’s there. And let’s be honest, sometimes the sheer absurdity of the experience is just plain hilarious.

And let’s be honest, sometimes the sheer absurdity of the experience is just plain hilarious.

unnormalised: Like the time the overhead bin popped open mid-flight and a shower of sarees cascaded down onto the passengers. Or the time the pilot came on the PA system to announce, "Ladies and gentlemen, we are experiencing a slight turbulence due to weather. Please fasten your seatbelts and enjoy the chai." Enjoy the chai?! Dude, we're about to hit an air pocket!

Or the time the pilot came on the P-A system to announce, "Ladies and gentlemen, we are experiencing a slight turbulence due to weather. Please fasten your seatbelts and enjoy the chai." unnormalised: The staff are so nice though, and sometimes they don't even care that you have a backpack that's way bigger than the regulation size of 55 x 40 x 20 cm. And, let’s be real, no other airline is going to give you a complimentary copy of "India Today" magazine from last month.

And, let’s be real, no other airline is going to give you a complimentary copy of "India Today" magazine from last month.

unnormalised: So, yeah, Air India. It’s a mess. It’s unpredictable. It’s often frustrating. But it's also uniquely Indian, and somehow, that makes it endearing. Just go in prepared, with a sense of humor, a good book, and maybe a few extra snacks. And for the love of all that is holy, avoid the mystery curry. Happy flying! I'll be sure to bring a mask and hand sanitizer, and I'll try to forget I paid Rs. 12,000 for this experience.
